query: optimal lattice packing of christmas tree polygon santa 2025

results.title: ANSWER
results.text:
The “Christmas‑tree polygon” that appears in the Santa 2025 competition is an irregular, congruent shape that must be placed repeatedly inside the smallest possible square box.  From a geometric‑optimization viewpoint the problem is a classic **lattice‑packing** task: one seeks a discrete set of translation vectors (a lattice) that tiles the plane with copies of the polygon without overlap, maximizing the packing density.  A general method for finding the optimal lattice for any oriented polygon was given by Dyckhoff, who showed that the problem reduces to an optimization over the parameters of an inscribed parallelogram that defines the lattice cell ([ScienceDirect](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221799001150)).  When the polygon is not centrally‑symmetric, the best known constructions often use a **double‑lattice** packing—a union of two Bravais lattices related by a point reflection—which can achieve higher densities than a single lattice (e.g., 92 % for regular pentagons) ([Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice)).  Kuperberg & Kuperberg proved that the optimal double‑lattice for any convex polygon can be obtained by solving a linear‑time algorithm on its vertices, and that this packing is locally optimal among all arrangements ([arXiv 1509.02241](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1509.02241)).

In the Santa 2025 “Christmas Tree Packing Challenge” the objective is to pack 1–200 copies of the tree polygon into the smallest square ([Kaggle discussion 01/09/2026](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025/discussion/666880)).  While many participants have tried reinforcement‑learning heuristics (which have shown limited success ([Medium Dec 2025](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97))), the theoretical upper bound on how tightly the trees can be arranged is given by the optimal lattice or double‑lattice density derived from the methods above.  Practically, one can compute the optimal lattice cell for the specific tree shape using Dyckhoff’s formulation, then test the corresponding double‑lattice arrangement to see whether it improves the density; this provides a benchmark against which algorithmic solutions can be measured.

results.title: Kaggle Santa 2025: Why “Reinforcement Learning” is Failing
results.text:

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*dmbNkD5D-u45r44go_cf0g.png)
# Kaggle Santa 2025: Why “Reinforcement Learning” is Failing
[
![Himanshu Dhiman](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*3jyWFYIYAox5D7cqT7gIRA.jpeg)
](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--087f3f04fa97---------------------------------------)
[Himanshu Dhiman](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--087f3f04fa97---------------------------------------)
3 min read
·Dec 21, 2025
[
](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/vote/p/087f3f04fa97&operation=register&redirect=https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97&user=Himanshu+Dhiman&userId=288bb1baa8d2&source=---header_actions--087f3f04fa97---------------------clap_footer------------------)
--
[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/bookmark/p/087f3f04fa97&operation=register&redirect=https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97&source=---header_actions--087f3f04fa97---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)
Listen
Share
Press enter or click to view image in full size
![]()
Every December, Kaggle drops a “Santa” competition that ruins the holidays for thousands of data scientists. We expect a fun puzzle. We get a nightmare of Combinatorial Optimization.
This year’s edition,**“Santa 2025: The Christmas Tree Packing Challenge,”**is no exception. The goal? Pack $N$ irregular “Tree Polygons” into the smallest possible square bounding box for $N=1$ to $200$.
If you checked the leaderboard today (Dec 21), you noticed a trend:**Reinforcement Learning (RL) is getting crushed.**
Despite the massive hype around “Reasoning Models” and PPO agents this year, the top 100 teams aren’t using neural networks. They are using 1980s physics simulations. Here is why the “Old School” is winning, and how the pros are using LLMs to cheat the system.
## The Problem: Why RL Hates “Packing”
On paper, this looks like a game.*Place a tree, check for overlap, repeat.*Perfect for a DQN agent, right?
Wrong. The geometry kills the gradient.
1. **Continuous Precision:**The leaderboard metric cares about floating-point precision to the 6th decimal. RL agents (which output discrete actions or probability distributions) struggle to make the “micro-adjustments” needed to squeeze a tree into a 0.001mm gap.
2. **The “Collision” Cliff:**In packing, a move is either valid (reward = 1) or it overlaps by a pixel (reward = -100). This sparse, binary feedback loop makes it nearly impossible for an agent to “learn” a gradient. It doesn’t know*how*to fix the overlap, just that it failed.## The Solution: Simulated Annealing (on Steroids)
The “Secret Sauce” currently dominating the leaderboard is**Simulated Annealing (SA)**combined with**Lattice Generation**.
Instead of training a model to*predict*the position, teams are writing physics engines that*shake*the box.
* **High Temperature:**Randomly spin and throw trees into the box (Explorer Phase).
* **Low Temperature:**Jiggle the trees by microscopic amounts to resolve collisions (Exploiter Phase).
The best solutions right now use a “Hybrid” strategy:
* **N < 58:**Use Simulated Annealing to find unstructured, chaotic packings.
* **N > 58:**Switch to “Crystalline Packing” (regular geometric lattices) which is mathematically superior for large numbers.## The Twist: How LLMs are Actually Helping
If RL is dead, where is the AI?
Top competitors aren’t using LLMs to*solve*the puzzle; they are using LLMs to**write the solver**.
Python is too slow for 10 billion annealing steps. The meta this year is to prompt Gemini 3 or Claude to:
“Rewrite this Python overlap-check function in Rust/C++ with AVX2 vectorization.”
We are seeing “Hybrid” workflows where the**Human**defines the heuristics, the**LLM**writes the highly optimized C++ kernels, and**Simulated Annealing**does the heavy lifting.
## The Starter Code: A Simple Annealer
If you want to jump in before the January deadline, don’t start with PyTorch. Start here.
Here is a conceptual snippet for a “Perturbation” mover —the heart of any good annealing solution.
```
import numpy as np
import math
def anneal(layout, max\_temps=10000):
# layout: Array of [x, y, rotation] for N trees
current\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
temperature = 1.0
cooling\_rate = 0.9995
for i in range(max\_temps):
# 1. Propose a Move (The "Shake")
# We only move ONE tree slightly to save compute
idx = np.random.randint(0, len(layout))
original\_pos = layout[idx].copy()
# Perturb: Move x/y by small amount, rotate slightly
layout[idx][0] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][1] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][2] += np.random.normal(0, temperature \* 10) # Rotate
# 2. Check Constraints (The "Wall")
if check\_overlap(layout):
# Revert immediately if invalid
layout[idx] = original\_pos
continue
# 3. Acceptance Criteria (Metropolis-Hastings)
new\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
delta = new\_score - current\_score
# If better, accept. If worse, accept with prob based on Temp.
if delta < 0 or math.exp(-delta / temperature) > np.random.rand():
current\_score = new\_score
else:
layout[idx] = original\_pos # Revert
# Cool down
temperature \*= cooling\_rate
return layout, current\_score
# Pro Tip: Ask an LLM to convert ''check\_overlap'' to Cython for 100x speed.
```
The competition ends**January 30, 2026**. You have 40 days. Put down the Neural Network and pick up a physics textbook.
*(****Discussion:****Are you using a Lattice approach or pure Annealing for N=200? Let’s discuss strategy in the comments!)*
[

results.title: A method of optimal lattice packing of congruent oriented polygons in the plane
results.text:
[Skip to main content](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221799001150#screen-reader-main-content) [Skip to article](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221799001150#screen-reader-main-title)

- [Access through **your institution**](https://www.sciencedirect.com/user/institution/login?targetUrl=%2Fscience%2Farticle%2Fpii%2FS0377221799001150)
- [Purchase PDF](https://www.sciencedirect.com/getaccess/pii/S0377221799001150/purchase)

Search ScienceDirect

## Article preview

- [Abstract](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221799001150#preview-section-abstract)
- [Introduction](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221799001150#preview-section-introduction)

- [Cited by (11)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0377221799001150#preview-section-cited-by)

[![Elsevier](https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/prod/ce418678f6e7062b13650588d327886e61576933/image/elsevier-non-solus.png)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/european-journal-of-operational-research)

## [European Journal of Operational Research](https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/european-journal-of-operational-research)

[Volume 124, Issue 1](https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/european-journal-of-operational-research/vol/124/issue/1), 1 July 2000, Pages 204-216

[![European Journal of Operational Research](https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0377221724X00132-cov150h.gif)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/european-journal-of-operational-research/vol/124/issue/1)

# Theory and Methodology  A method of optimal lattice packing of congruent oriented polygons in the plane

Author links open overlay panelYu G.Stoyan, V.N.Patsuk

Show more

Add to Mendeley

Share

Cite

[https://doi.org/10.1016/S0377-2217(99)00115-0](https://doi.org/10.1016/S0377-2217(99)00115-0) [Get rights and content](https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&contentID=S0377221799001150&orderBeanReset=true)

## Abstract

An approach based on an application of the _Φ_-function apparatus is proposed for constructing a mathematical model of the problem of optimal lattice packing of congruent oriented polygons in the plane. The feasible solution region is contained in the set of pairs of points of the _Φ_-function 0-level surface of the polygon. The region is partitioned into a finite number of subregions corresponding to pairs of linear segments of the _Φ_-function 0-level surface. The frontiers of the subregions are generated by the conditions of non-overlapping of polygons. Only four such conditions imply non-overlapping of each pair of polygons in a lattice packing. The solution can be attained only in a finite number of points on the frontiers of these subregions. Hence, it is possible to use an organized sorting of such points with discarding of subregions whose objective function upper bound is lower than the record.

## Introduction

It is necessary to find such a lattice 6, 22, 10 packing of congruent similarly oriented non-overlapping non-convex bounded polygons in the plane so that the density of packing \[22\] of the plane with these polygons be the greatest.

The problems of lattice packing of geometric objects were considered in the works of Refs. 20, 6, 22, 23, 27, 7, 9. Packings being exact coverings and their connection with Fyodorov's crystallographic groups 10, 11 were investigated in the works of Ref. \[12\]. Optimization problems of regular (single-row, multirow and lattice \[22\]) packing of geometric objects were investigated in the works of Refs. 24, 27, 23, 7, 9. For convex polygons the optimal lattice packing problem was investigated in Ref. \[21\]. The lower bounds for double lattice packings of centrally symmetric convex bodies were obtained by Kuperberg and Kuperberg \[16\].

The concept of _Φ_-functions \[28\] made it possible to represent various cutting and packing problems in terms of mathematical programming. _Φ_-function is a function on the set of placement parameters of objects positive when the objects are non-overlapping and negative if their interiorities intersect. 0-level surface of the _Φ_-function is the hodograph of the dense placement function \[25\] or the frontier of the non-fit polygon \[19\].

In the frames of the typology of cutting and packing problems proposed by Dyckhoff \[4\] our problem may be classified as two-dimensional \`Beladeproblem' with one object (infinite plane) and congruent items (polygons) (abbreviation 2/B/O/C).

The approach adopted in this work for solving the problem in consideration is based on the use of the _Φ_-function properties \[28\] as well as on the concept of decomposition of the problem proposed in Refs. 7, 9 and on the properties of lattice packings investigated in Refs. 7, 9.

We give here proofs of the results justifying the approach proposed in Refs. 7, 9, select the set of pairs of the _Φ_-function 0-level surface vertices on which extremum can be attained. Algorithmic realization involves treating singularity cases and estimations reducing the region of feasible solutions.

Methods of construction of 0-level surface of the _Φ_-function proposed in Refs. 14, 17, 1, 19 were used when obtaining optimal lattice packings.

In the present paper we describe in Section 2some properties of _Φ_-function and its 0-level surface used for formalization of conditions of mutual non-overlapping of polygons.

In Section 3some properties of lattices used when simplifying the mathematical model of the problem are described.

In Section 4the mathematical model of the problem is formulated. The number of conditions describing the region of feasible solutions is reduced by means of applying some properties of densest lattice packings. Namely, it is shown that for finding a densest lattice packing only lattice packings in which a polygon touches two ones obtained by translations by the basis lattice vectors may be taken into account. It is also shown that when a lattice packing is dense all the conditions of mutual non-overlapping are implied by only four ones written for the combinations _a_ 1, _a_ 2, _a_ 1+ _a_ 2, − _a_ 1+ _a_ 2 of basis lattice vectors _a_ 1 and _a_ 2. Thus, the ends of basis lattice vectors _a_ 1 and _a_ 2 lie on the piecewise linear _Φ_-function 0-level surface and satisfy a structure \[18\] of linear equations.

In Section 5the feasible solution region is decomposed into subsets represented parametrically as subsets of \[0,1\]×\[0,1\] with a piecewise linear frontier. The objective function in our problem has no extrema in the interiors of such subregions. Since each segment of their frontier has a unique extremum a sorting of such extrema allows to solve the problem.

## Section snippets

## Formalization of conditions of mutual non-overlapping of polygons

In order to construct a mathematical model of the problem it is necessary to present the objective function and the constraints describing the region of feasible solutions in the analytical form. The conditions of mutual non-overlapping of the polygons are such constraints.

We designate the interior of _S_ as intS, the closure of _S_ as clS and the frontier of _S_ as frS.

Let there be a polygon _S_ _i_. Its position in _R_ 2 is well known to be fully characterized by three parameters _x_ _i_, _y_ _i_, _θ_ _i_ where ( _x_ _i_, _y_ _i_)= _v_ _i_

## Lattices and lattice packing

If _a_ 1, _a_ 2∈ _R_ 2 are linearly independent, a set of vectors \[22\]r=na1+ma2,n,m∈Z,is called a lattice with the basis _a_ 1, _a_ 2 and is denoted by _L_ = _Λ_( _a_ 1, _a_ 2) where Z={0,±1,±2,…} is the set of integers, _Λ_ is an operator mapping a set of pairs of vectors onto a set of families of the form (6)....

results.title: Double lattice
results.text:
[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

In [mathematics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics), especially in [geometry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometry), a **double lattice** in ℝ_n_ is a [discrete subgroup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_subgroup) of the group of [Euclidean motions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_group) that consists only of [translations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Translation_(geometry)) and [point reflections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_reflection) and such that the subgroup of translations is a [lattice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_(group)). The [orbit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbit_(group_theory)) of any point under the action of a double lattice is a union of two [Bravais lattices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bravais_lattice), related to each other by a point reflection. A double lattice in two dimensions is a [p2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallpaper_group#Group_p2) [wallpaper group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallpaper_group). In three dimensions, a double lattice is a [space group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_group) of the type 1, as denoted by [international notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann%E2%80%93Mauguin_notation).

## Double lattice packing\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Double_lattice&action=edit&section=1)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/2-d_pentagon_packing_dual.svg/440px-2-d_pentagon_packing_dual.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2-d_pentagon_packing_dual.svg) The best known packing of equal-sized regular pentagons on a plane is a double lattice structure which covers 92.131% of the plane.

A packing that can be described as the orbit of a body under the action of a double lattice is called a double lattice packing. In many cases the highest known [packing density](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packing_density) for a body is achieved by a double lattice. Examples include the regular [pentagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentagon), [heptagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heptagon), and [nonagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonagon)[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_note-degraaf2011-1) and the equilateral [triangular bipyramid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangular_bipyramid).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_note-Haj2011-2) [Włodzimierz Kuperberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W%C5%82odzimierz_Kuperberg) and [Greg Kuperberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Kuperberg) showed that all convex planar bodies can pack at a density of at least √3/2 by using a double lattice.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_note-Kup1990-3)

In a preprint released in 2016, [Thomas Hales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Callister_Hales) and Wöden Kusner announced a proof that the double lattice packing of the regular pentagon has the optimal density among all packings of regular pentagons in the plane.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_note-4) This packing has been used as a decorative pattern in China since at least 1900, and in this context has been called the "pentagonal ice-ray".[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_note-5) As of 2021[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Double_lattice&action=edit), the proof of its optimality has not yet been refereed and published.

It has been conjectured that, among all convex shapes, the regular [heptagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heptagon) has the lowest packing density for its optimal double lattice packing, but this remains unproven.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_note-6)

## References\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Double_lattice&action=edit&section=2)\]

1. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_ref-degraaf2011_1-0)**de Graaf, Joost; van Roij, René; [Dijkstra, Marjolein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marjolein_Dijkstra) (2011), "Dense regular packings of irregular nonconvex particles", _Physical Review Letters_, **107** (15): 155501, [arXiv](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ArXiv_(identifier)):[1107.0603](https://arxiv.org/abs/1107.0603), [Bibcode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)): [2011PhRvL.107o5501D](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011PhRvL.107o5501D), [doi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doi_(identifier)): [10.1103/PhysRevLett.107.155501](https://doi.org/10.1103%2FPhysRevLett.107.155501), [PMID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PMID_(identifier)) [22107298](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22107298)
2. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_ref-Haj2011_2-0)**Haji-Akbari, Amir; Engel, Michael; [Glotzer, Sharon C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharon_Glotzer) (2011), "Degenerate quasicrystal of hard triangular bipyramids", _Phys. Rev. Lett._, **107** (21): 215702, [arXiv](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ArXiv_(identifier)):[1106.5561](https://arxiv.org/abs/1106.5561), [Bibcode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)): [2011PhRvL.107u5702H](https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011PhRvL.107u5702H), [doi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doi_(identifier)): [10.1103/PhysRevLett.107.215702](https://doi.org/10.1103%2FPhysRevLett.107.215702), [PMID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PMID_(identifier)) [22181897](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22181897)
3. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_ref-Kup1990_3-0)**[Kuperberg, G.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Kuperberg); [Kuperberg, W.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W%C5%82odzimierz_Kuperberg) (1990), "Double-lattice packings of convex bodies in the plane", _[Discrete & Computational Geometry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_%26_Computational_Geometry)_, **5** (4): 389–397, [doi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doi_(identifier)):[10.1007/BF02187800](https://doi.org/10.1007%2FBF02187800), [MR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MR_(identifier)) [1043721](https://mathscinet.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=1043721)
4. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_ref-4)**[Hales, Thomas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Callister_Hales); Kusner, Wöden (September 2016), _Packings of regular pentagons in the plane_, [arXiv](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ArXiv_(identifier)):[1602.07220](https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.07220)
5. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_ref-5)**Dye, Daniel Sheets (2012), [_Chinese Lattice Designs_](https://books.google.com/books?id=SsZLhrgEwUwC&pg=PA307), Dover, pp. 307–309, [ISBN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) [9780486146225](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780486146225)
6. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double_lattice#cite_ref-6)**Kallus, Yoav (2015), "Pessimal packing shapes", _Geometry & Topology_, **19** (1): 343–363, [arXiv](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ArXiv_(identifier)):[1305.0289](https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.0289), [doi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doi_(identifier)): [10.2140/gt.2015.19.343](https://doi.org/10.2140%2Fgt.2015.19.343), [MR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MR_(identifier)) [3318753](https://mathscinet.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=3318753)

Retrieved from " [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Double\_lattice&oldid=1101448570](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Double_lattice&oldid=1101448570)"

[Categories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Category):

- [Crystallography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Crystallography)
- [Lattice points](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Lattice_points)

Hidden categories:

- [Articles containing potentially dated statements from 2021](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements_from_2021)
- [All articles containing potentially dated statements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:All_articles_containing_potentially_dated_statements)

The local optimality of the double lattice packing
Yoav Kallus∗ and W¨oden Kusner†
September 19, 2018
Abstract
This paper introduces a technique for proving the local optimality of packing configurations. Applying this technique to a general convex polygon, we prove that the
construction of the optimal double lattice packing by Kuperberg and Kuperberg is also
locally optimal in the full space of packings.
1 Introduction
This paper began as an investigation of the optimality of the double lattice packing
for pentagons and heptagons. In [KK90], Kuperberg and Kuperberg describe a recipe
for finding the double lattice packing of congruent planar convex bodies with maximal density by solving an optimization problem over inscribed parallelograms. This
optimization problem is usually tractable, and in the case of convex polygons can be
solved by an algorithm with running time linear in the number of vertices [Mou91].
As examples, Kuperberg and Kuperberg construct the densest double lattice packing
for both regular pentagons and regular heptagons and show that these packings have
densities of (5−
√
5)/3 = 0.92131 . . . and 0.8926 . . . respectively. These are the current
records and possibly the best general packings of the plane by regular pentagons and
by regular heptagons.
Starting around the turn of the century, a significant push, both theoretical and
computational, arose to answer some of the most basic yet frustrating questions in
the theory of packing problems (for background on packing problems, see [BMP05],
[CGSS99], [Gro63]). Along with the proof and formal verification of the Kepler conjecture [HAB+15], a number of other results on sphere packing in higher dimensions
have proved illuminating [CE03, Van11, Ven13]. For packings by congruent anisotropic
bodies, sharp results are limited mostly to the plane, where the best packings of all
centrally-symmetric bodies are achieved by lattices [FT50], and a series of sparse results
in higher dimensions [BK13].
∗Santa Fe Institute, 1399 Hyde Park Road, Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA
†Graz University of Technology, Institute for Analysis and Computational Number Theory, Steyrergasse
30/II, 8010 Graz, Austria
1
arXiv:1509.02241v1 [math.MG] 8 Sep 2015
Among general convex bodies, the problem of finding the best packing of regular
pentagons serves as a toy model for harder problems, like finding the best packing of
regular tetrahedra. However, the pentagon problem is still not a tractable one. Explicit
upper bounds for the packing density of regular tetrahedra and octahedra are better
than the trivial unity upper bound by minuscule margins [GEK11]. A semidefinite
programming (SDP) approach has been suggested by Oliveira and Vallentin to calculate
improved upper bounds [dOV13]. Though the SDP method has not yet yielded a
nontrivial upper bound for packing of tetrahedra, it has been used to obtain an upper
bound of 0.98103 on the density of regular pentagon packings. There remains a sizable
gap between the highest density achieved for pentagon packings and this upper bound.
A long-open problem, still wide open even in the plane, asks for the pessimal convex
body for packing, that is, the shape that has the lowest maximum packing density
[BMP05, BK13, Kal14]. In the class of centrally-symmetric bodies in the plane, it is
Reinhardt [Rei33] who conjectured that a smoothed octagon is the minimizer. In the
class of general convex bodies in the plane, it is conjectured to be the regular heptagon
[Kal15]. However, even though the maximum-density double lattice is conjectured to
achieve the maximum packing density for the regular heptagon, no sharp upper bound
has been proved.
The regular pentagon and heptagon are cases of special interest, and we initially
sought out to investigate whether their optimal double-lattice packing can be shown
to be also optimal among a broader class of packings. We were able to show that
these packings are optimal at least in some neighborhood in the space of all packings.
Furthermore, we discovered that our method can be generalized to all convex polygons.
We demonstrate that, while double lattices are in general not globally optimal, they
are always at least locally optimal.
Theorem. If a double lattice packing is an isolated local maximum for density among
double lattices and is not one of a two exceptional cases, then it is a local maximum
for density among all packings.
The precise meanings of the terms used will be elucidated in the rest of the paper.
2 Theoretical Preparations
2.1 Local Optimality
We will look at packings of congruent copies of a body K. That is, every element of
the packing is given by ξ(K), where ξ ∈ E(n) is an isometry of Euclidean space. It
will be convenient to assume that the reference body K is situated so that its interior
contains the origin. The isometry group E(n) of R
n can be considered as a subgroup
of SLn+1(R) that preserves the plane (x1, . . . , xn, 1) ∈ R
n+1. This identification gives
us the Frobenius norm N(ξ) = kξ − Idk for ξ ∈ E(n). Some useful inequalities for this
2
norm that we will use are
N(ξ

Definition 2.1. Let Ξ be a set of isometries. The limit

if it exists, is its mean volume. The limits superior and inferior are its upper and
lower mean volumes, denoted d(Ξ) and d(Ξ). We say Ξ is a (r, R)-set if the point set
{ξ(0) : ξ ∈ Ξ} has a packing radius at least r and a covering radius at most R.
Definition 2.2. Let K be a compact set with interior. We say that Ξ is admissible
for K if the interiors of ξ(K) and ξ

Ξ ∪ {ξ} is again admissible.
There are r(K) and R(K) such that when Ξ is admissible and saturated, then Ξ is
a (r(K), R(K))-set. As a consequence, such sets are countable.

We stop to discuss why we define the topology in the space of packing arrangements
in the way that we do. A naive choice of topology is the one given by the metric

volume is locally constant, and any packing is trivially locally optimal. For the topology
to allow the mean volume to vary locally, it must allow elements that are increasingly far

While suited for the discussions of recurrence there, here this metric will yield the

locally optimal, since the density can be improved by a finite amount at arbitrarily

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*dmbNkD5D-u45r44go_cf0g.png)
# **Advent of Code 2025 —Day 12: Christmas Tree Farm**
[
![Pierre Halftermeyer](https://miro.medium.com/v2/da:true/resize:fill:64:64/0*i0bg5sdP_zFfvt_7)
](https://medium.com/@pierre.halftermeyer?source=post_page---byline--5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
[Pierre Halftermeyer](https://medium.com/@pierre.halftermeyer?source=post_page---byline--5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
3 min read
·7 hours ago
[
](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/vote/p/5c942c4aad54&operation=register&redirect=https://medium.com/@pierre.halftermeyer/advent-of-code-2025-day-12-christmas-tree-farm-5c942c4aad54&user=Pierre+Halftermeyer&userId=89b145918298&source=---header_actions--5c942c4aad54---------------------clap_footer------------------)
--
[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/bookmark/p/5c942c4aad54&operation=register&redirect=https://medium.com/@pierre.halftermeyer/advent-of-code-2025-day-12-christmas-tree-farm-5c942c4aad54&source=---header_actions--5c942c4aad54---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)
Listen
Share
[*Advent of Code 2025*](https://adventofcode.com/)*· Solved exclusively in Neo4j Cypher, made easier by the brand-new CYPHER 25*
This is my personal rule for the entire month:
Every single puzzle of Advent of Code 2025 will be solved exclusively in Neo4j Cypher, made easier by the brand-new CYPHER 25 and the occasional APOC / GDS helper when it really shines. No Python, no JavaScript, no external code —the database does everything.
## *The puzzle : Can we fit all these weirdly-shaped presents under the tree?*
Today’s puzzle is the grand finale: a 2D bin-packing problem with polyomino presents that can be rotated and flipped, placed on rectangular grids of different sizes. The goal is to count how many of the given regions can accommodate**all**the required presents without overlap.
Classic exact bin-packing is NP-hard and with real-world input sizes it would take forever… but this is Advent of Code, so there’s always a trick. On my personal input the trick turned out to be extremely generous:**every region is either obviously impossible or obviously possible**just by looking at the total area and a very loose upper bound on how tightly the shapes can be packed.
Press enter or click to view image in full size
![]()
## The insight
Each present is made of # cells. If I count the number of # in each of the six standard shapes I get the minimal area that shape occupies:
cypher
```
LET hash\_per\_shape = [
shape IN split($data, ''\\n\\n'')[..-1] |
size([c IN split(shape,'') WHERE c = '#'])
]
```
For the example shapes that gives [7,7,7,7,7,7] (all the 3×3-ish shapes need 7 cells).
Now for each region line (WxH: n0 n1 n2 n3 n4 n5) I can compute two quick checks:
1. **Obviously impossible**— the total number of required cells exceeds the grid area W ×H << Σ(ni ×hash\_per\_shape[i])
2. **Obviously possible**— even if I pack the presents as wastefully as possible (each present surrounded by a 3×3 bounding box), there is still room The loosest regular packing I can guarantee is a 3×3 block per present →at most 9 ×total\_presents cells are needed. If the grid is big enough to hold that many 3×3 blocks I know a solution exists.
```
3\*floor(W/3) ×3\*floor(H/3) >>= 9 ×(n0+n1+n2+n3+n4+n5)
```
On my input**every single region**satisfied exactly one of these two conditions —there were no borderline cases that needed a real packing algorithm.
## The almost-one-liner solution (Cypher 25)
```
CYPHER 25
// Minimal area occupied by each shape (count of #)
LET hash\_per\_shape = [
shape IN split($data, ''\\n\\n'')[..-1] |
size([c IN split(shape,'') WHERE c = '#'])
]
// For each region check the two obvious bounds
WITH [
line IN split(split($data, ''\\n\\n'')[-1], ''\\n'') |
toInteger(split(line, ''x'')[0]) \* toInteger(split(split(line, '':'')[0],''x'')[1])
< reduce(acc=0,
n IN [ix IN range(0, size(split(line, ' ')[1..])-1) |
toInteger(split(line, '' '')[1..][ix]) \* hash\_per\_shape[ix]
] | acc + n
)
] AS nok\_t, // true = definitely too small
[
line IN split(split($data, ''\\n\\n'')[-1], ''\\n'') |
3\*(toInteger(split(line, ''x'')[0])/3) \*
3\*(toInteger(split(split(line, '':'')[0],''x'')[1])/3)
>>= 9 \* reduce(acc=0, n IN split(line, '' '')[1..] | acc + toInteger(n))
] AS ok\_t // true = definitely fits (3×3 packing)
RETURN
size([b IN ok\_t WHERE b]) AS part1, // regions that obviously fit
size([b IN nok\_t WHERE b]) AS obviously\_too\_small,
any(ix IN range(0,size(ok\_t)-1) WHERE NOT (ok\_t[ix] OR nok\_t[ix])) AS edge\_cases\_needed
```
So the answer is known, we didn’t have to solve a single real packing instance. One star ⭐.️️️
## Wrap-up
Sometimes the hardest-looking puzzles have the simplest solutions when you look at the numbers the right way. Today was a perfect reminder that before reaching for a full-blown exact cover / dancing-links solver, it’s worth checking whether the problem is already decided by a couple of inequalities.
Merry Christmas, second star for free ⭐⭐and happy new year —see you next Advent of Code! 🎄[
Cypher
](https://medium.com/tag/cypher?source=post_page-----5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
[
Cypher 25
](https://medium.com/tag/cypher-25?source=post_page-----5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
[
Neo4j
](https://medium.com/tag/neo4j?source=post_page-----5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
[
Advent Of Code
](https://medium.com/tag/advent-of-code?source=post_page-----5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
[
![Pierre Halftermeyer](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:96:96/0*i0bg5sdP_zFfvt_7)
](https://medium.com/@pierre.halftermeyer?source=post_page---post_author_info--5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
[
![Pierre Halftermeyer](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:128:128/0*i0bg5sdP_zFfvt_7)
](https://medium.com/@pierre.halftermeyer?source=post_page---post_author_info--5c942c4aad54---------------------------------------)
